persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: John JoachimBecher
persons.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

persons.name: JohnMayow
persons.description: Cornish physiologist and chemist, investigated respiration especially. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

works.name: Micrographia: or Some Physiological Descriptions of Minute Bodies Made by Magnifying Glasses. With Observations and Inquiries Thereupon
works.author: Robert Hooke

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: AndreasLibavius
persons.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

persons.name: JeanRey
persons.description: French physician and chemist.

works.name: Essays de Jean Rey sur la Recerche de la cause pour laquelle l'Estain et le Plomb augmentent de poids quand on les calcine,
works.author: Jean Rey

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: BryanHiggins
persons.description: Irish chemist and natural philosopher who developed a form of the atomic theory of matter. Worked in London, St Petersburg and Jamacia. Uncle of William Higgins.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamHiggins
persons.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

persons.name: PierreBayen
persons.description: French chemist best known for experiments on water toxicity. He also performed experiements related to the discovery of oxygen.

persons.name: BryanHiggins
persons.description: Irish chemist and natural philosopher who developed a form of the atomic theory of matter. Worked in London, St Petersburg and Jamacia. Uncle of William Higgins.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: Democritus
persons.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

works.name: A Comparative View of the Phlogistic and Antiphlogistic Theories
works.author: William Higgins

persons.name: CornelisDrebbel
persons.description: Dutch engineer and inventor. He was the builder of the first operational submarine in 1620 and an innovator who contributed to the development of measurement and control systems, optics and chemistry.

persons.name: AdairCrawford
persons.description: A British chemist, physician, and fellow of the Royal Society. He was a pioneer in the development of calorimetric methods for measuring the specific heat capacity of substances and the heat of chemical reactions.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: EdmundGoodwyn
persons.description: Physician who studied with Thomas Beddoes at the University of Edinburgh.
